feed.title: Combined summary - Signature and Script Independent Hierarchy for Deterministic Wallets.

entry.title: Combined summary - Signature and Script Independent Hierarchy for Deterministic Wallets.
entry.summary: Developer Robert Spigler has raised concerns about the current standards for deterministic wallets, arguing that there are issues with mixing keys and scripts in the same layer. To address this problem, he proposed a new standard called "Signature and Script Independent Hierarchy for Deterministic Wallets," which separates keys and scripts by creating a new hierarchy. The proposal aims to prevent key reuse across single signature and multisignature wallets, across ECDSA and Schnorr signatures, and between the same wallet types. According to Robert, descriptor wallets can solve the problem of having to check all script types on recovery. In multisignature wallets, each cosigner stores their extended private key (xprv) and the wallet descriptor for backup. For single signature wallets, only one signature is needed. However, Jochen Hoenicke disagreed with Robert's proposal, stating that existing BIP39/BIP44/BIP49/BIP84 wallets can recover all accounts using just the seed words without the need for public keys or derivation paths.The debate highlights the tradeoffs between simplicity and security in wallet backups. In an email conversation between Craig and Robert Spigler regarding the proposal, concerns were raised about the security of multisig wallets. Craig suggested that if someone has the threshold and all the cosigner seeds, the funds in a multisig wallet could potentially be discovered by checking a handful of standard derivation paths/script types. However, Robert believes that his proposed BIP would excel in multisig and initially designed it for that purpose before extending it to single sig wallets. Nevertheless, ghost43 and Jochen Hoenicke brought up important issues with the proposed BIP concerning single sig wallets, so Robert decided to revert it back for multisig derivations to address all concerns. The updated version of the BIP can be viewed on Github.David Harding commented on Craig Raw's post about the proposed standard for Bitcoin wallet backup, stating that most wallets today allow for restoration with just a seed so the burden of wallet backup is not shifted to the user. Ghost43 raised concerns about the amount of work required when restoring a wallet from seed under the new proposal, and David Harding explained that the scanning work in both cases is essentially the same and that there is no actual key reuse between different scripts.The discussion centered around the wallet software, including BIP44/49/84, and the new BIP XY, with the potential risk of reusing keys for older wallet software that is unaware of newer versions' actions. The proposal to encode script type in the derivation is being questioned as output descriptors are becoming more prevalent, with two options suggested: 1) Use derivation paths that do not encode the script type and educate users to backup output descriptors in addition to their seed words or 2) Use a standard set of derivation paths that encode the script type, ensuring fund recovery even if users do not back it up by checking against common derivations.In conclusion, Spigler's proposed BIP seeks to create a clearer hierarchy for multisignature and single signature wallets. The proposal gets rid of redundant data in the key record, separates keys/scripts, makes full use of descriptors, and prevents key reuse. While there are differing opinions on the best method for backing up deterministic wallets, the debate highlights the tradeoffs between simplicity and security in wallet backups.
